abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Agricultural Credit
            Project for Pakistan was unsatisfactory. The project only
            partially achieved its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was negligible, sustainability is
            unlikely, and the performance of the Bank was marginally
            satisfactory while the Borrower's was deficient.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First, the
            political will to effect critical changes, especially in
            interest rates and granting autonomy to ADBP, should have
            been critically appraised. Second, a broader financial
            sector operation, like the ongoing Financial Sector
            Deepening and Intermediation Project, is more appropriate.
            Third, institutional weaknesses and financial policy
            deficiencies need to be addressed before Bank funds are
            channeled on a major scale. Fourth, overlapping periods
            between the previous and follow-up project are best avoided
            to learn from the past. Fifth, it is clear that establishing
            target loan recovery rates while providing short-term
            incentives, if any, is not an adequate response to the
            underlying problems. Sixth, government ownership of banks
            virtually eliminates a proper incentive framework.
            Therefore, serious consideration should be given to an
            insistence on privatization. Finally, unless
            agricultural/rural credit interest rates are identical to
            the market-based interest rates, participation of the
            commercial banks in any rural credit operation will never
            become meaningful.
